title_sort: harry stafford to walt whitman, 7 november 1877
title: Harry Stafford to Walt Whitman, 7 November 1877
text: Thanks for the dollarBlank No. 1. THE WESTERN UNION TELEGRAPH COMPANY. The rules of this Company require that all messages received for transmission, shall be written on the message blanks of the Company, under and subject to the conditions printed thereon, which conditions have been agreed to by the sender of the following message. O. H. PALMER, Sec'y. J. H. WADE, Pres't. Dated, November 7 1877Received at Kirkwood N.J.New JerseyTo Dear Friend Walt:I received your letter yesterday P.M. was glad to hear from you. H.G. was down to see us last Sunday, he walked down and stade[stayed] all night and came over with me to the depot and the[then] went on the cars from here to Phila, he wants me to come up Saturday and stay all night with him, but I will not do it, we can go over for a little while and then come back to your house and stay all night. I will have to go over for a few hours any way for if I don't Mother will get on her ear she was very much put out because I did not go and see him the last time I was up in your house. I am feeling well, now but have not for some time untill today, sick about half of the time, but I guess I will be all right now. I have an invitation to a party to nighttonight but I think that I will have to stay home and tend store for Ed, he wishes to go over that will be an excuse for me H.G. tells me that you are well and doing fine sais[says] that you come over to see them every evening. You must enjoy it or you would not do it, I think it will be good for you to keep it up for going out will give you strength and exercise both, I would lik[like] to be down with you. I suppose that you go to Woolstons once in a while, how does Elmer like the folkes[folks] there? I think that I would like to come up and board there gaain[again] if I ever come to Camden again to work I want to board withe[with] them. Hope you are still well, father has been quite sick but is better at present, he will not live long I am afraid he is sick more this fall than he has been for a long time, Mont & still at shucking the have got some one[someone] to help them now I balive[believe]. Well I have filled up the paper with nothing and I will have to stop, good by[bye] write soon.True and loving friendH Stafford Harry Stafford to Walt Whitman, 7 November 1877
